title: What are some good books on the history of autocracies? - Quora

response.answer_text: A lot will depend on just which autocracy interests you, and your larger purpose in reading about it. For France, I found the relevant sections of James Collins’ overview of the history of the French state to be helpful: Amazon.com: The State in Early Modern France (New Approaches to European History) (9780521130257): Collins, James B.: Books For a good overview of the English monarchy in the same period, Marc Kishlansky’s volume in the Penguin History of England is quite good: A Monarchy Transformed: Britain, 1603-1714: Kishlansky, Mark: 9780140148275: Amazon.com: Books If you want a broad overview of the topic written by a political theorist, you can do a lot worse than volume 3 of S.E. Finer’s History of Government. It is older scholarship, but breathtaking in its breadth—clearly a lifetime effort to write: The History of Government from the Earliest Times, Vol. 3: Empires, Monarchies, and the Modern State: Finer, Samuel E, Finer, S E (Late Emeritus Professor of: 9780198207917: Amazon.com: Books If you can give me a better sense of what you are seeking to learn, I can do a better job guiding you into the historical literature on this topic.
